sec.title: The Midwest Nursing Research Society Advances Science to Improve Health
sec.p: The 2013 Midwest Nursing Research Society (MNRS) Conference held in Chicago was a smashing success! We would like to thank the Planning Committee, the host schools, and the local planning committee for all their hard work in putting together an outstanding experience for the conference attendees.

A number of awards were highlighted during the Awards Ceremony portion of the conference. The specific awards and the recipients are listed below. Please refer to the MNRS website for additional details on these awards.

sec.title: Honor a Researcher
sec.p: The purpose of this program is to provide MNRS members an opportunity to honor their research colleagues for outstanding endeavors related to research. The funds raised through this special recognition program are directed to the MNRS Foundation to support the MNRS Grants program.
This year’s recipients are,
Indiana University School of Nursing
Nominated by Marion Broom, PhD, RN, FAAN
Indiana University School of Nursing
Nominated by Marion Broom, PhD, RN, FAAN

Research Title: Symptom Recognition in Heart Failure
Three MNRS Dissertation Research Grants were awarded to the following recipients:
University of North Dakota—College of Nursing
Research Title: Maternal Group B Streptococcus Serum Markers
The Ohio State University College of Nursing
Research Title: Pathways to Shortened Gestation Among Black Women
University of Illinois at Chicago
Research Title: Access to Care: Determinants of Maternal Health Care Use in Malawi
MNRS/Council for the Advancement of Nursing Science Dissertation Research Grant was awarded to:
Indiana University School of Nursing
Research Title: Healthcare Utilization in HIV Positive Transgender Women
MNRS/ANF Research Grant was awarded after the 2012 MNRS Conference to:
University of Nebraska Medical Center
Research Title: Expanding the Typology of Life Transitions in Women Using a Clinical Data–Based Approach
MNRS/Sigma Theta Tau Research Grant was awarded after the 2012 MNRS conference to:
University of Iowa
Research Title: Parent Perceptions of Sexual Education Needs of Children with Autism Spectrum Disorders

sec.title: MNRS Lifetime Achievement Award
sec.p: The MNRS Lifetime Achievement Award recognizes an MNRS member who has significantly advanced the profession of nursing either through an extensive program of research or creation of environments where research can flourish, and whose distinguished career yielded outstanding and noteworthy accomplishments.

Dr. Karen F. Pridham, University of Wisconsin–Madison. Karen F. Pridham, PhD, RN, FAAN, was recognized for her extensive and pivotal program of research advancing nursing science, theory, education, and practice in the care of children and their families.

sec.title: Harriet H. Werley New Investigator Award
sec.p: The Harriet H. Werley New Investigator Award recognizes the contribution of a new investigator who has conducted nursing research that has the potential to enhance the science and practice of nursing.
Dr. Marianne Smith, University of Iowa. Dr. Smith’s research focuses on improving the health of older adults with psychiatric morbidities living in the community.

sec.title: John A. Hartford Foundation Award for Leadership in Geriatric Nursing Research
sec.p: This award recognizes an MNRS member who has demonstrated outstanding leadership in geriatric nursing science and who has impacted quality of care for older adults in the MNRS region. The winner of this year’s award is Dr. Jean Wyman, University of Minnesota School of Nursing. Jean Wyman, PhD, RN, FAAN, has devoted her career to the study of interventions to promote the health, functioning, and quality of life of older adults in community and long-term care settings.

sec.title: Senior Scientist Recognition Program
sec.p: This award recognizes outstanding Senior Scientists whose accomplishments in scholarship, mentorship, and service are noteworthy and vital to building the knowledge base in nursing. Awardees include,
The Ohio State University College of Nursing
Dr. Beckett is recognized for her contributions to explicate the pathobiology of “sickness” symptoms that occur with infection and cancer.
Loyola University Chicago, Marcella Niehoff School of Nursing
Dr. Januesek is recognized for her contributions in understanding the impact of psychosocial stress on biological and behavioral outcomes in vulnerable populations.
Indiana University School of Nursing
Dr. Hickman is recognized for her contributions in improving the care provided to older adults near the end-of-life through research on decision making in the LTC and oncology settings.
Indiana University School of Nursing
Dr. Drauker is recognized for her contributions in generating basic knowledge regarding how individuals heal from experiences of interpersonal violence.

sec.title: Distinguished Contribution to Research in the Midwest
sec.p: This award recognizes the contributions of a member who has conducted or promoted research that has enhanced the science and practice of nursing in the MNRS region. This year’s recipient is Dr. Janet Carpenter, Indiana University. Janet Carpenter, PhD, RN, FAAN, is recognized for her important and substantial program of research on understanding and managing menopausal symptoms in breast cancer survivors and in midlife women without cancer.
Congratulations to all the award winners! We are very proud of all of you.
Linda L. Chlan

sec.title: MNRS Foundation News
sec.p: What a great 2013 conference in Chicago! Congratulations to all those involved in planning, staffing, and participating in a stimulating exchange of scholarship and colleagueship. The Foundation Board of Trustees looks forward to working more closely with the Emerging Scholars Network (ESN) to enhance their involvement in our activities. To that end, Marilyn Swan, a doctoral student from South Dakota State University, has agreed to serve as the ESN representative to the Board, and we welcome her input and participation.

The Foundation also celebrated an important Endowment achievement—reaching our interim goal of US$200,000. THANK YOU to all who made this significant milestone possible and also to those who joined the Founder’s Circle or made other donations at the conference. We truly appreciate your ongoing support of research. This year, there were more than 40 grant applications—so many, in fact, that we were unable to fund many well-qualified applications. While this speaks to the high quality of scholarship in MNRS, it also makes our Foundation mission even more compelling.

Fundraising activities included a vibrant karaoke evening complete with brilliant vocals and dance moves, and an outstanding silent auction, with Loyola University, Chicago Niehoff School of Nursing, winning the coveted roller coaster trophy for raising the most money. Some of you commented to me that you were frustrated by the short hours available to bid on auction items. Members of the Program Planning committee will take your comments and evaluation of these activities into consideration for future events. I also personally invite you to send your suggestions on how to improve our fundraising efforts at the St. Louis conference; all ideas regarding WHAT we might do and WHEN to best hold events are most welcome. You may direct your recommendations to me at Kathleen-buckwalter@uiowa.edu, and be assured they will be taken seriously and conveyed to conference planners.

sig-block.sig: Kathleen C. Buckwalter, PhD, RN, FAAN President, MNRS Foundation
